awd_titl_txt: The Interplay of Replication and Transcription in Fragility of Structured DNA
awd_abstract_narration:
The integrity of DNA is fundamental to life, but sometimes DNA can break, leading to loss of genetic material or even cell death. Interestingly, certain areas of chromosomes, known as fragile sites, tend to break more frequently. These fragile sites are a frequent source of DNA mutations, for example loss or gain of genetic material. Thus, an understanding of the basis of chromosome fragility will provide insight into causes of disease and of genome evolution. This topic is of great interest to college students studying molecular biology and genetics, and a Molecular Genetics Project Laboratory was developed to provide a research experience to 16 students a year, investigating the causes of chromosome fragility using a yeast model system. The goal of the course is to identify new pathways that protect against fragility, and give the students an authentic research experience. This project will support both the laboratory class as well as follow-up experiments by undergraduate and graduate students, to gain new knowledge about important pathways that prevent deleterious mutations. 

Many fragile sites in the human genome are associated with both DNA structures that interfere with replication and transcribed regions. It is suspected that the co-incidence of structure-forming DNA sequences, transcription, and replication may combine to cause these regions to be prone to fragility, however the interplay between them is poorly understood. Genetic systems have been developed in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to measure chromosome breaks that are induced at specific structure-forming repetitive DNA sequences that cause DNA fragility. In this system, transcription state and replication timing through the DNA structure can be controlled, to directly measure the consequences for DNA breakage. The role of proteins in causing or protecting against DNA breaks will be determined, including the action of identified nucleases Mlh1-Mlh3 and Mus81. These tools will be employed to elucidate the contributions and interplay of transcription and replication in causing fragility at two physiologically relevant fragile sequences: (1) expanded CAG repeats and (2) a long AT repeat from the human fragile site FRA16D. The knowledge gained will enhance understanding of mechanisms of fragility and the resulting genome instability that leads to chromosomal deletions and rearrangements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The human genome contains many DNA sequences that are repetitive in nature, and some of these can form alternative DNA structures different than the standard double helix. It is estimated that up to 10% of the human genome is composed of structure-forming DNA repeat sequences. Some of these sequences, such as CAG/CTG repeats, are known to expand to cause inherited diseases. Expanded repeats are also fragile sites of the human genome, known to break and require repair, and repeat expansions can occur during this repair process. Other repeat sequences are not known to expand to cause inherited disease but are still fragile sites within the human genome that are prone to chromosome breakage. DNA breaks can cause deletions or other loss of genetic material, which often occurs in cancer cells. On the other hand, these same characteristics of repetitive DNA may contribute to genome evolution. Thus, it is paramount to determine how the machinery of the cell is able to copy (replicate) these repetitive DNA sequences to avoid either repeat expansions or deletions of genetic material occurring during break repair. Understanding how fragility occurs within these repeats and the resulting genome instability can provide fundamental new insights into mutational processes that occur in eukaryotic cells.

Many fragile sites in the human genome are associated with transcribed regions, which are regions being copied into RNA to make the proteins that do the work of the cell. It was suspected that the co-incidence of structure-forming DNA sequences, transcription, and replication combine to cause these regions to be prone to fragility, however the interplay between them was not understood. We developed genetic systems in budding yeast cells (baker’s yeast) to measure chromosome breaks that are induced at specific structure-forming repetitive DNA sequences that cause DNA fragility, under different conditions of transcription or replication. We tested the role of cellular pathways in causing or protecting against DNA breaks under these different conditions. The objective of this proposal was to use these tools to elucidate the contributions of transcription and replication in causing DNA fragility at two physiologically relevant fragile sequences: (1) expanded CAG repeats and (2) a long AT repeat sequence found at a human fragile site often deleted in cells undergoing replication stress.

Using this approach, we made several new discoveries. We showed that a replication fork stalled by a long AT repeat is the target of cleavage by a nuclease complex called SMR in yeast (SMX in humans) and that this accounts for the observed breaks that occur. The SMR complex contains 3 separate nucleases that all contributed to cleavage of the cruciform structure formed by the AT repeat. We collaborated on a study showing that these same types of cleavage events occur at many long AT repeats in the human genome. We also identified that a specialized DNA polymerase, called Pol Zeta, is important for replicating through these AT repeat structures to prevent replication fork stalling and the resulting chromosome breaks. In our studies of CAG repeats, we discovered that synergistic chromosome fragility occurred upon mutation of two different RNA processing pathways, indicating that these pathways normally work in different ways to promote genome stability. We identified stalled RNA polymerase and titration of a single-strand binding protein called RPA by excess unprocessed RNAs as two mechanisms that work in synergy, both causing increased transcription-replication collisions. Lastly, we found that CAG/CTG repeats being transcribed were susceptible to cleavage by a kind of nuclease that cells express to defend against viruses, and that this can inadvertently lead to their expansion or contraction (gain or loss of repeat units).  

In addition to the scientific advances, this project also aimed to train students in scientific research methodology and give opportunities to students from diverse backgrounds to engage in authentic scientific research. This was done in 2 ways. First, trainees at all levels were engaged in doing independent research in the Freudenreich lab: 2 postdoctoral fellows, 2 PhD students, 2 MS students, and a total of 20 undergraduate students were involved in the research projects funded by this grant. Second, a class was developed to be able to give a course-based undergraduate research experience to even more students, and a total of 70 students took the class and had the opportunity to engage in an open-ended research project to discover genes that protect against chromosome fragility at AT repeat tracts. Thus, a total of 96 trainees at various levels gained research experience through this project. A goal of this project was to have a broader impact than the research outcomes, to inspire students about the importance and potential outcomes of basic research, and to provide them with an experience that will impact their views about science and the worth of basic research in whatever career they choose.
